sen.j: 中坊 秀祐（なかのぼう ひですけ）は、安土桃山時代から江戸時代前期にかけての武将。
sen.e: Hidesuke NAKANOBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.
Hidesuke NAKANOBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.
Hidesuke NAKANOBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.
He was the second son of Morisuke NAKANOBO.
He was the second son of Morisuke NAKANOBO.
He was the second son of Morisuke NAKANOBO.

sen.j: 中坊氏は菅原道真の後裔柳生永珍の弟が山城国笠置寺の宗徒となって中坊氏を称したことに始まる。
sen.e: The Nakanobo clan was founded by a younger brother of Nagayoshi YAGYU, who was a descendant of SUGAWARA no Michizane, who became a follower of Kasagi-dera Temple in Yamashiro Province and called himself Nakanobo.

The Nakanobo clan was founded by a younger brother of Nagayoshi YAGYU, who was a descendant of SUGAWARA no Michizane; he became a follower of Kasagi-dera Temple in Yamashiro Province and called himself Nakanobo.
sen.cmt: , who became→; he becameとしました。
sen.e: The Nakanobo clan was founded by a younger brother of Nagayoshi YAGYU, who was a descendant of SUGAWARA no Michizane; he became a follower of Kasagi-dera Temple in Yamashiro Province and called himself Nakanobo.

sen.j: 一時、奈良氏と称したが、秀祐の曽祖父中坊秀友が中坊氏と称した。
sen.e: Although the clan adopted the name of Nara temporarily, Hidetomo NAKANOBO, who was Hidesuke's great-grandfather, adopted the name of Nakanobo.
Although the clan adopted the name of Nara temporarily, Hidetomo NAKANOBO, who was Hidesuke's great-grandfather, adopted the name of Nakanobo.
Although the clan adopted the name of Nara temporarily, Hidetomo NAKANOBO, who was Hidesuke's great-grandfather, adopted the name of Nakanobo.

sen.j: また、藤原北家の流れを組む系譜も残されている（『寛政重修諸家譜』）。
sen.e: One genealogy states that the clan derived from the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan ("Kansei Choshu Shokafu" [genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu]).
One genealogy states that the clan derived from the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan ("Kansei Choshu Shokafu" [genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu]).
One genealogy states that the clan derived from the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan ("Kansei Choshu Shokafu" [genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu]).

sen.j: 初め、松永久秀に仕えて被官として度々多聞院英俊を訪問していたことが『多聞院日記』に遺されている。
sen.e: According to "Tamonin nikki diary," he often visited Eishun TAMONIN as a hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of Hisahide MATSUNAGA in his early career.
sen.cmt: 多聞院英俊：ウェブ上に、奈良興福寺の子院多聞院の院主である長実房英俊(ちょうじつぼうえいしゅん)との記載があります。
sen.e: According to the "Tamonin Nikki" diary, he often visited Eishun TAMONIN as a hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of Hisahide MATSUNAGA in his early career.
sen.cmt: "Tamonin nikki diary"→the "Tamonin Nikki" diaryとしました。
sen.e: According to the "Tamonin Nikki" diary, he often visited Eishun TAMONIN as a hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of Hisahide MATSUNAGA in his early career.

sen.j: 次いで豊臣秀長、豊臣秀保に仕え、大和国吉野郡で3500石 (単位)の知行を与えられた。
sen.e: Then, he successively served Hidenaga TOYOTOMI and Hideyasu TOYOTOMI, and granted chigyo (enfeoffment) of 3,500 koku in Yoshino district, Yamato Province.
Then, he successively served Hidenaga TOYOTOMI and Hideyasu TOYOTOMI, and granted chigyo (enfeoffment) of 3,500 koku in Yoshino County, Yamato Province.
Then, he successively served Hidenaga TOYOTOMI and Hideyasu TOYOTOMI, and granted chigyo (enfeoffment) of 3,500 koku in Yoshino County, Yamato Province.

sen.j: 後に筒井定次に仕えたが定次から寵愛され、それをいいことに次第に専横の振る舞いが目立つようになったとされる。
sen.e: Later, when he served Sadatsugu TSUTSUI, he was highly regarded by Sadatsugu, which is said to make him gradually grow arrogant.
Later, when he served Sadatsugu TSUTSUI, he was highly regarded by Sadatsugu, which is said to have made him gradually grow arrogant.
sen.cmt: which is said to make him→which is said to have made himとしました。
sen.e: Later, when he served Sadatsugu TSUTSUI, he was highly regarded by Sadatsugu, which is said to have made him gradually grow arrogant.

sen.j: さらに島清興と常に対立し、遂には定次に対して清興を讒言し、筒井氏から追放に追い込んだとされている（筒井騒動）。
sen.e: He even came into conflict with Kiyoki SHIMA, and it is said that he ultimately slandered Kiyoki to Sadatsugu to expelled him from the Tsutsui clan (the Tsutsui disturbance).
sen.cmt: 筒井騒動：対訳としては確認できません。
sen.e: He even came into conflict with Kiyooki SHIMA, and it is said that he ultimately slandered Kiyooki to Sadatsugu to expel him from the Tsutsui clan (the Tsutsui Disturbance).
sen.cmt: Kiyoki SHIMA→Kiyooki SHIMA、to expelled→to expel に修正、Tsutsui Disturbanceとしました。
sen.e: He even came into conflict with Kiyooki SHIMA, and it is said that he ultimately slandered Kiyooki to Sadatsugu to expel him from the Tsutsui clan (the Tsutsui Disturbance).

sen.j: 慶長13年（1608年）6月、駿府城の徳川家康に対して定次の不行状を訴えたが、これが原因で定次は改易に追い込まれた。
sen.e: In July, 1608, he filed a petition to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA complaining Sadatsugu's vice, which forced Sadatsugu to be deprived of his position.
sen.cmt: 慶長13年（1608年）6月は西暦1608年7月12日となるようです。http://maechan.net/kanreki/
sen.e: In July, 1608, he filed a petition to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA complaining Sadatsugu's vice, which forced Sadatsugu to be deprived of his position.
In July, 1608, he filed a petition to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA complaining Sadatsugu's vice, which forced Sadatsugu to be deprived of his position.

sen.j: 寵臣である秀祐がこのような訴訟を行なった理由は家康との裏取引があったためといわれており、筒井氏改易後に幕臣として取り立てられ、奈良奉行に任じられている。
sen.e: It is said that Hidesuke, who was Sadatsugu's favorite retainer, sued Sadatsugu because he made a deal with Ieyasu, and he became a retainer of the Shogun and was appointed a member of Nara bugyo after the Tsutsui clan had been deprived of their position.

It is said that Hidesuke, who was Sadatsugu's favorite retainer, sued Sadatsugu because he made a deal with Ieyasu, and he became a retainer of the Shogun and was appointed a member of Nara bugyo after the Tsutsui clan had been deprived of their position.

It is said that Hidesuke, who was Sadatsugu's favorite retainer, sued Sadatsugu because he made a deal with Ieyasu, and he became a retainer of the Shogun and was appointed a member of Nara bugyo after the Tsutsui clan had been deprived of their position.

sen.j: しかし、筒井氏旧臣の恨みはおさまらず、慶長14年（1609年）2月29日、伏見でかつての同僚であった山中氏に暗殺された。
sen.e: However, enmity of old retainers of the Tsutsui clan against him remained, and he was assassinated by the Yamanaka clan, who were former colleagues in Fushimi on April 3, 1609.
However, enmity of old retainers of the Tsutsui clan against him remained, and he was assassinated by the Yamanaka clan, who were former colleagues in Fushimi on April 3, 1609.
However, enmity of old retainers of the Tsutsui clan against him remained, and he was assassinated by the Yamanaka clan, who were former colleagues in Fushimi on April 3, 1609.

sen.j: 秀祐の死後、家督は嫡子中坊秀政が継いだ。
sen.e: After Hidesuke died, Hidemasa Nakanobo, who was his heir and son, took over as head of the family.
After Hidesuke died, Hidemasa NAKANOBO, who was his heir and son, took over as head of the family.
After Hidesuke died, Hidemasa NAKANOBO, who was his heir and son, took over as head of the family.
